text: We are planning on building a graphical interface for differential equations.  It seems to us that Julia is the platform for differential equation solvers.  The idea is to build a system of differential equations using a graph representation which then gets translated into a function that can then be evaluated.  Does anyone know about any efforts in this direction?  Can anyone suggest a good starting point for defining and displaying graphs that we can extend for our purpose.  Thanks

text: For my PhD I was using Comsol for solving differential equation and it was OK, but the experience was not super nice

text: I said it before too that i think this is a great idea (the gui interface). If we can have something like Toolboxes for Matlab (like for example, curve fitting toolbox), it would really put julia over the top

text: Also check out Causal.jl. It is a causal modeling framework similar to Simulink, but without the GUI front end.

elements.text: Also check out Causal.jl. It is a causal modeling framework similar to Simulink, but without the GUI front end.

text: Under the hood it’s all graph-based connections

elements.text: Under the hood it’s all graph-based connections

text:
>  There is Simulink, but that is more for electrical engineers
It really isn't. All of the SimScape modelling packages make it so other fields can use it - and I think a fair number of industrial people build their models in it so they are portable to other development teams in the companies.

elements.text: There is Simulink, but that is more for electrical engineers

It really isn't. All of the SimScape modelling packages make it so other fields can use it - and I think a fair number of industrial people build their models in it so they are portable to other development teams in the companies.

text: Simulink is really big in Aerospace controls engineering too.

elements.text: Simulink is really big in Aerospace controls engineering too.

text: It is basically the industry standard control engineering software - no matter the industry their engineers usually do the models and control design in it.

elements.text: It is basically the industry standard control engineering software - no matter the industry their engineers usually do the models and control design in it.

text:
There's this AlgebraicJulia framework/ecosystem that I found recently from JuliaCon 2020 defining systems and models in an category theory type of framework which define how each component behaves ( I think ?), which then allows one to generate wiring diagrams from connecting components together and simulate the entire model. The video linked goes over Catlab.jl, Petri.jl, and SemanticModels.jl packages. The Github page for Catlab.jl says there's no GUI for it, but the package could be used as a backend for a GUI application.

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7zr2qnud4XM>

attachments.title: JuliaCon 2020 | AlgebraicJulia: Applied Category Theory in Julia | James Fairbanks
